questions.question_text:
The SYSDATE function displays the current Oracle Server date as:

21-MAY-19


You wish to display the date as -


MONDAY, 21 MAY, 2019 -

Which statement will do this?

choices.D: SELECT TO_CHAR(SYSDATE, 'FMDAY, DDTH MONTH, YYYY') EROM DUAL;
choices.A: SELECT TO_DATE(SYSDATE, 'FMDAY, DD MONTH, YYYY') FROM DUAL;
choices.B: SELECT TO_CHAR(SYSDATE, 'FMDD, DAY MONTH, YYYY') FROM DUAL;
choices.C: SELECT TO_CHAR(SYSDATE, 'FMDAY, DD MONTH, YYYY') FROM DUAL;

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
Its intresting...BOTH queries return the same result

select prod_list, prod_name from products where prod_list = any (select prod_list from products)

select prod_list, prod_name from products where prod_list <> any (select prod_list from products)
'A' can not be correct. The subquery will list 10, 20, 30, 40 while the main query will return any product name that is not equal to any of the subquery list (<> ANY). So, A cannot be correct.

Selected Answer: A
Only A is correct
E would be correct if it's NOT IN and <> ALL

Selected Answer: A
A is correct
Maybe E is supposed to be using IN ..., then it would work.

comments.content: if C or E said will NOT give the same result then that would be true.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: A
A is a correct answer 
Using NOT IN or <> ANY will not give the same result.

choices.D: Using <> ANY will display all the product names.
choices.B: Using IN will display all the product names.
choices.E: Using NOT IN or <> ANY will give the same result.
choices.C: Using NOT IN or <> ANY will give the same result.
choices.A: Using <> ANY will display all the product names except the product named Fork.

discussion.content:
The condition from subquery is same for all tables i.e. data from sub query comes with employee_id > 125

if the sal > 2000 then values will insert in Special_sal
if the sal <2000 then values will insert in SAL_HISOTORY & MGR_HISTORY

CHATGPT IS WRONG 100%.

D is Correct

Selected Answer: D
In INSERT ALL we can have multiple INTO clauses under conditional statements. So both INTO statement will be executed under ELSE condition.

Selected Answer: C
Using chatgpt4, answer given is C. someone pls verify

Expected Outcome Based on Conditions:
For employee_id = 100 with salary = 25000:

Meets SAL > 20000, so data is inserted into special_sal.
Data is also inserted into mgr_history because the condition for the mgr_history table insertion doesn't depend on the salary.
For employee_id = 110 with salary = 18000:

Does not meet SAL > 20000, so data is inserted into sal_history.
Data is also inserted into mgr_history regardless of the salary because there's no conditional logic preventing this in the provided statement.
For employee_id = 120 with salary = 21000:

Meets SAL > 20000, so data is inserted into special_sal.
Data is also inserted into mgr_history regardless of the salary.
C is correct you can CHATGPT

Selected Answer: D
D is correct

choices.D: Only if the salary is 20000 or less and the employee id is less than 125, insert EMPLOYEE_ID, MANAGER_ID, and SALARY into the MGR_HISTORY table.
choices.A: Only if the salary is 20000 or less and the employee id is 125 or higher, insert EMPLOYEE_ID, MANAGER_ID, and SALARY into the MGR_HISTORY table.
choices.C: Regardless of salary, only if the employee id is less than 125, insert EMPLOYEE_ID, MANAGER_ID, and SALARY into the MGR_HISTORY table.
choices.B: Regardless of salary and employee id, insert EMPLOYEE_ID, MANAGER_ID, and SALARY into the MGR_HISTORY table.

discussion.content:
Answer is BEF
https://oracle-base.com/articles/misc/temporary-tables

Selected Answer: BEF
A GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE in Oracle cannot have a PUBLIC SYNONYM. Synonyms, especially public ones, are meant to provide a consistent and global alias to database objects. However, Global Temporary Tables (GTTs) have session-specific or transaction-specific data, and allowing a public synonym for such a table could lead to confusion or conflicts due to its session-dependent behavior.
why BDE is the answer? Correct answer is BEF

Selected Answer: BEF
BEF is correct

choices.E: A GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE can have multiple indexes.
choices.B: A GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE can be referenced in the defining query of a view
choices.F: A trigger can be created on a GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE.
choices.C: DML on GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLES generates no REDO.
choices.D: A GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE cannot have a PUBLIC SYNONYM.
choices.A: A GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLE can have only one index.

questions.question_text: Which three statements are true about GLOBAL TEMPORARY TABLES? (Choose three.)

Examine the description of the BOOKS_TRANSACTIONS table:

//IMG//


Examine this partial SQL statement:

SELECT * FROM books_transactions

Which two WHERE conditions give the same result? (Choose two.)

choices.C: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND transaction_type = 'RM' OR member_id IN ('A101', 'A102');
choices.D: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND (transaction_type = 'RM' OR member_id IN ('A101', 'A102');
choices.A: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND (transaction_type = 'RM' AND member_id = 'A101' OR member_id = 'A102');
choices.E: WHERE (borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND transaction_type = 'RM') OR member_id IN ('A101', 'A102');
choices.B: WHERE borrowed_date = SYSDATE AND (transaction_type = 'RM' AND (member_id = 'A101' OR member_id = 'A102'));
